Consider changing to full bracketing: (i), (ii), (iii) etc, unless you have specific reasons for preferring i)

'In 2012 Basque is located' does not work in English: it would have to be 'In 2012, Basque was located'.  But this phrasing makes it look like 2012 is already pretty distant, and makes readers expect the next sentence to start 'Five years later, in 2017, ...'  Suggested rephrasing: 'As of 2012, Basque was located... It was... There were...' To me, this would sound like an appropriate *present-day* state of the art. The English preterite does not necessarily project events deep back into the past.
suggested: The Basque language in the digital age  (IMHO it makes 'Basque' stand out better than if capital letters are lavished on all and every concept: Digital Age, etc.)
(This should be OK after the issue of 'Greece' running into the margin has been fixed. These issues are taken care of later, at finalization of typesetting by LangSciPress staff.)

column8: Did some of the main text go into the footnote, or conversely? This sentence is not OK, and neither is the 1st sentence of the footnote.
It will come out as: Erro et al. (2010)
as above: From parsing and generation to the real world

... or any other name, but use it consistently :-) 'Answer focus identificator' sounds OK to me, because 'identifier' sounds *static* to me: an identifier is something such as the DOI or ISBN of a publication (a tag that uniquely identifies an object), whereas with the -ator suffix a process of identification is clearly suggested. Maybe my background as a speaker of Romance languages is a bias here, and other readers' suggestions are needed!
I don't know to what extent 'Structured Queries' count as a proper name = a specific technique. I'd recommend 'Structured queries vs. target co-occurrence-based selection'.
Consider a hyphen between *language* and *related* as together they modify *processes*.
Verb *aim* commonly takes *to* infinitives complements, but noun *aim* rarely does. Consider *the aim of detecting*
'abnormally' seems very negative; not appropriate here.
The adverb 'recently' does not add much to the argument, and does not sound quite right for an event of now 5 years ago.
For states of the USA: use the two-letter state code. (See guidelines)
*translation and creation of* or *translating and creating*
I think 'continuing education' is the English equivalent of *formation continue* (if that is the intended meaning)
Would seem clearer as: 'WordNet: An electronic lexical database'.

The expression 'Basque ... has to make a great effort' personifies the Basque language. If this is a deliberate choice, then fair enough. A milder phrasing (maybe more 'scientific', in a sense) would be to say 'Basque, like other minority languages, requires a great effort to address this challenge'.
(see above on need to harmonize: all-US, or all-UK/Australia/NZ)

Alignment of left & right columns unclear. EUSMT is opposite 'Speech synthesis': should be under 'Machine translation'. Suggestion: watch out for alignment, and align text at top of cell. Vertical spacing is also an issue: 'Phraseology... extractor' and 'Ihardetsi' should be in 2 different cells, right? This needs to be rendered visually through vertical spacing.
It should just be 'shown in \figref{...' and it will come out OK.

Only the 1st word of book titles is capitalized (and given names, of course). Hence:   In *Multilingual information access evaluation I: Text retrieval experiments, 10th workshop of the Cross-Language Evaluation Forum, CLEF 2009*

Some lines are separated by a big interlinear (vertical) interval, others not. I was not able to guess what distinction this points to. Do the lines not separated by a vertical interval belong to the same paragraph, and describe the same resource? That is, are the Basque Dependency Treebank and Basque Propbank the same tool/ set/ suite...?

space needed after 'for example'.  I think it would also look better if the quotation marks were included in the portion in italics (=italicized). Currently they seem to float in mid-air: it looks as if something were typographically wrong.
Only 1st word capitalized in title (plus proper names, 1st word following colon or stop).  Thus: EusPropBank: Integrating semantic information in the Basque Dependency Treekbank.

US conventions seem to be followed in some places, for instance in the previous line: 'specialized', not 'specialised'. This should be harmonized. (I'm told that the '-ise' usage is on the way out in Britain too, but I'm not sure. It's still standard in Australia and New Zealand = more conservative areas from this point of view.)

Harmonize: all-caps or not *for both modules*. Suggestion: no caps except for 1st word (Answer focus identificator and Ill-formed questions rejecter), or, perhaps better, no caps at all (italics are enough to delineate these technical expressions).
I don't think the expression 'at eye level' is used in this context

You have this upper case here, lower case in the next instance, and then upper case again. The motivation is opaque.

column8: if possible, consider making the following wording changes:  - *Training data of out-of-domain* → *Out-of-domain training data* - *Training data of in-domain* → *In-domain training data* - *Testing data of in-domain* → *In-domain testing data*
just remove it, it isn't used in the text.

first of all, Figures 3 and 4 have apparently been mixed up: the text states that Figure 4 illustrates all ten experiments, whereas it's Figure 3 that has 10 points along the x-axis. (additionally, the Figure 3 caption states that it pertains to the Business domain, but cross-referencing that with Table 5, it's clear that the Business domain numbers correspond to the data points in Figure 4 instead.)  second, here are some suggestions to improve both figures:  - using dual y-axes should be avoided if possible; if it can't be avoided, then both axes should be explicitly labeled within the figure itself (the figure currently provides a legend, not axis labels) - the x-axis should be labeled as well - points along the x-axis are equidistant, as if they represented a nominal / ordinal variable, whereas in reality, they're a numeric variable and should be represented as such (especially if the goal is to highlight correlations) - given that both data series represent corpus sizes, why is one represented using columns and the other using connected points? - English uses a decimal point instead of a decimal comma - the 15.11 improvement is the largest one, it should therefore be the last datapoint on the far right of the plot  this is what the result could look like, if the rest of the authors' original intentions is adhered to: <http://imgur.com/a/SBdT7>

the in-domain language model was the best of the three according to the original article, not in the authors' setting. also, the footnote is so short it makes much more sense to integrate the information into the sentence instead. altogether:  *According to the original article, the best adaptation method*
or put the formula in the  running text

As mentioned before, this is exactly what I'd do to make a bullet point list in Turkish. However, I think a different standard has been established in the English language. Hence, I propose using an opener such as 'This offers various advantages such as / including:', making the first letters of each item lowercase, ending them with semi-colons (except for the second to last, which should be ended with '; and' and the last one, which should be ended with a period. Not an absolute necessity, of course. Merely a suggestion.

column8: There are varying instructions on this, but the most relevant one appears to be in the Unified Style Sheet, which goes:  'conference proceedings titles according to the name of the society, including the meeting’s acronym in parentheses. Do not include “proceedings of the” or “papers from the”.'  Not that it is the most important thing in the world, but perhaps this could be considered.
